title: If the Jewish religion is true, what does that mean for non-Jews? - Quora

response.answer_text: It means: be good people. That’s pretty much it! Here, I’ll explain. In Judaism, we have what are called the mitzvot (singular: mitzvah). There are 613 of them, and we’re commanded to do (or not do) all of them. These include ones you’ve probably heard of—like not eating pork—and ones where you’re probably like “no shit, you’re kidding me, really?”—like the mitzvah that says it is a man’s duty to satisfy his wife sexually. (Yes, really.) This is what being the “chosen people” means: we have been chosen to fulfill the 613 mitzvot and live moral, upright lives, according to the laws of Torah. We are to be a light unto the nations—which doesn’t mean we should try to make other people Jews, it means that ideally other people will look at what we do and go “wow, what a good idea!” Here’s a real-life example: one of the Talmudic rabbis said we should say 100 blessings daily. I took this as a personal challenge, and while I haven’t actually hit 100 yet, thanking G-d for everything that crosses my mind has changed my entire way of thinking. I’m not joking when I say that today one of my blessings was “G-d, I’m cranky and pissy and hurt and sooooo tired of coworker drama. Thank You for giving me the foresight to fill my Starbucks card this week so I can enjoy something sweet, relax, and have a better night.” I relayed this personal challenge, the 100 blessings in a day, to my boss. She’s Catholic, but she loved the idea and I’m pretty sure she’s actually doing it, because I’m seeing the same changes in her that I saw in myself when I took up this challenge. This is what it means to be the chosen people. So what if you’re NOT one of the chosen people? What if you’re a gentile? No problem, we’ve got you covered. All you have to do is follow the Noahide Laws, and you’ll be considered righteous among nations and to have a place in the world to come. BUT WHOA—Noahide Laws? You people have 613 mitzvot and there are MORE? Well, yeah, but there are only seven Noahide laws, and they basically boil down to “don’t be a dick.” Judaism also has no concept of sin in the sense that Christianity does. The word “chata,” often translated as “sin,” is more like “to have set a goal, and to have fallen short of the mark.” So, for example, last year I began to follow the most famous part of kashrut—the prohibition against eating pork. And I did pretty well, but then I found out the hard way that you should always check the ingredients on your bag of beef jerky. I didn’t fail utterly to keep this aspect of kosher! I just missed the mark of keeping it perfectly, all the time. For that matter, when I prayed about it I pretty much said “well, THAT was a mistake and also a learning experience. I’m sorry about that and next time I’ll check the actual ingredients.” And that’s all there is to it—you say you know you missed the mark, and you’re sorry, and then you check all future beef jerky purchases for the little kosher symbol to show G-d that you actually mean what you said. And you’re forgiven! G-d knows the difference between “oh shit who expects pork in beef jerky” and “you know what, G-d, screw you, I am eating this ENTIRE ham cooked in lard, just to spite you.” (This is different if you’ve broken a mitzvah that involves other people. Before Yom Kippur this year I had to go to someone in my synagogue and tell him that when we’d disagreed on a point about Israel I’d been talking shit about him and his opinion to one of my friends, instead of talking to him directly about why I felt he was wrong, and to ask his forgiveness. It’s a hard and humbling process, but until you’ve asked forgiveness from that person—who is not obligated to give it to you—then even G-d cannot forgive you.) So basically: do your best and don’t be a dick. That’s it. That’s all of Torah as it applies to gentiles. See you in the world to come!

Hang a square-bottom pyramid under a light, point up, and your shadow will be a square shape. The square is the true shadow of the pyramid.  Turn the pyramid without changing the shape at all, and in a particular sideways orientation, the shadow under the light will clearly be a triangle. The shadows in the shapes of a square and a triangle are both equally true. Religion is quite this way. There are an infinite number of true shadow shapes the pyramid can cast, even though there are more shadow shapes that would not be true to the pyramid. There are an infinite number of true religions, even though there are more possible religions that are not true. (For example, a religion that calls for murder, would not be considered true according to Jewish law.) Any one religion being true does not cause any other to be false. G-d is infinite, humans are infinitely variable, so of course, there are infinite potential true religions. Judaism does not, and never did, claim to be the only true religion for all people.
